/COMMIT_MSG.message: is this change expected to be compatible with release N when platform upgrade to N+1 with this update?

Very good question.

Yes, this new bit is a re-purposing of a reserved bit in the shared structure. See: (https://review.opendev.org/c/starlingx/metal/+/751558/6/mtce/src/heartbeat/mtceHbsCluster.h).

This bit has always been defaulted to zero which means 'heartbeat ok' which is precisely why the bit is called 'sm_heartbeat_fail'. Is set to 1 when SM -> hbsAgent heartbeat fails.

The shared struct size did not change.

If this update is not there and SM's is, then SM will always think that its heartbeat is ok.

If this update is present and SM's is not, then this update might set this bit but SM will not react to that.

Also and over-reaching, this hearteat messaging is only over localhost not between controllers.

As with all SM patches, this would be a reboot required patch and upgrade so there is no risk that the hbsAgent and SM are mismatched on a controller.

hooks/neutron_api_utils.py.message:
If extra-source is of the same type (eg. "cloud:") as the one defined in "openstack-origin", add_source will overwrite the content (ie. in the case of "cloud:", the content of /etc/apt/sources.list.d/cloud-archive.list).

I think "extra-source" and "extra-key" are used in another part of the charm to install Neutron plugins that are not officially packaged by the Ubuntu OpenStack team (ie. neutron-plugin). Two examples of extra-source are for Calico and Midonet.

This should not be needed and could mask a problem when packaging Ubuntu OpenStack. The problem described at LP#1805322 was caused by a non-stepped upgrade of OpenStack. The default OpenStack version (distro) in Xenial is Ocata, and the bug reporter tried to upgrade directly to Queens. A temporary upgrade to "cloud:xenial-pike" should have been triggered first.

Please check comments #9 and #10 on the referred bug.

across a mixed-version cluster... the un-upgraded nodes would've reported back an error, but (I guess the test is trying to demonstrate that) they would've at least restarted what they could.

I'm not sure how this test suite (CephTest) passed in the past. It includes a test_pause_and_resume test but charm-ceph-osd does not have such actions.

I think the OpenStack team should weigh in and see if the "service start=N stop=N" action should be split into "pause id=N" and "resume id=N" (and fallback to "all" when no id is passed. So "pause" would be the same as the current "service stop=all" and "resume" would be the same as "service start=all"). The caveat would be that we wouldn't be able to start and stop services as part of the same action (ie. "service start=1,3 stop=2", which would start two OSDs and stop one more)

I think this completely changes the logic of this method (as documented above) and will probably break other use cases.

How about not mixing self.variables and self.parent_data INTO self.variables, but keeping them separate?

The problem as I see it is, that we are accumulating all the parent data of previous runs.
Why do we change the order here? If I understand the comment correctly, the `reverse()`was on purpose.

The problem is, if we have 2 jobs A and B and we reverse the order, then the return values of B (which run later) are overwritten with those of A.

Previously, the self.variables were never updated, only merged.

I think because of this line here we are still keeping stale data around (from previous call to updateParentData()). If I'm not mistaken we can always re-construct the parent data from the parent builds. So I see no need to mix in the previous parent_data. This way you should also be able can to keep the below reverse() logic.
Let me rephrase that a bit: before calling updateParentData() for all parent jobs we need to (re-)init/clear job.parent_data in findJobsToRun().

Anyway, I agree with this change.

no, the other way around, that happens when the 'all-projects' client is used with a non-admin token (L162).

approx scenario:

- VM is assigned FIP and that has a record in a certain zone in Designate created
- zone in designate is deleted out of band
- ordinary user tries to delete such VM that has floating IP assigned
- L157 tries to find the zone (resolve name to uuid) using ordinary user's auth and tenant-scoped request
- L157 raises DNSDomainNotFound
- L162 tries the same auth, but now with "all-projects" request
- as the ordinary user lacks privileges to make such requests, Designateclient raises Forbidden, which, if uncaught, bubbles up to the 500 from Neutron
- VM is not deleted and is in ERROR state

Maybe better handle the NotFound exception here? I'm also not sure that the
DNSDomainNotFound exception would be handled properly here, I guess that would need another try: clause anyway.

Retry operation supports any operations except for Create VNF and Delete VNF. (e.g. Instantiate, Heal)
Retry operation identifies the target operation in FAILED_TEMP by vnflcmopoccId in the request, then it retries the operation. 
The operator is supposed to determine whether to retry by the error code of the operation.

doc/source/developer/specs/zuul-runner.r.message: How would this process look like? Would the runner supply a template inventory or would it take a simple one from the user and enrich it with the zuul variables?
I guess the runner would enrich the inventory as it already do with the nodepool nodeset.
Running a standalone launcher is probably not possible for the majority of the normal users dueto lack of access to cloud resources.
Ok next PS removes that part.

That should not be a blocker, access to cloud resources is something we can safely assume developer have, one way or the other, it could even be for free: https://aws.amazon.com/blogs/opensource/aws-promotional-credits-open-source-projects/
You can change this to a gender-neutral form (and shorten it too!) with "...shall require the user to provide copies of...".

Although not mutually exclusive, I see two use different use cases with different scopes that could perhaps benefit from being described in the spec:

1) Running a local build of a job that has already ran (i.e, it failed and I want to run it locally to see what happens under the hood)

2) Being able to run any job from any Zuul instance, tenant, project or pipeline regardless if it has run or not

An example for #1 would be to point zuul-runner at a build URL where it would automatically discover the zuul API server, job, manifest, inventory and variables (from zuul-info logs) and then re-run the job against a user-specified inventory. 
Something like:

    zuul-runner rerun http://zuul.openstack.org/build/d8dcc3aa89a34c919f5e8e1979d8c3bc --inventory /foo/bar

#2 requires a very flexible approach which is currently described in the spec but I think the main use case would be #1.
I think it's worth describing both use cases in the spec.
Next PS adds both use cases to the spec first section.
The nodes argument doesn't appear above -- are you replacing that with a user-supplied inventory file?  If so, that's missing too.

doc/source/reference/developer/specs/zuu.message: Can you describe how this process would look?  I don't see any description below of how a user would invoke zuul-runner to run a job that has already run.  I'm curious if you could point it at a zuul inventory file and have it automatically work?  How would it reproduce the previous merge state?

I think for the use case of "recreate a build that failed in the gate" it's important to have the exact merge state of the projects.  Zuul has that from the mergers (the mergers tell the executors exactly what to do), so we can expose that.

Next PS mention that this can be done using an inventory file indeed, or using the `--change-url` command line argument too.

To reproduce the exact merge state, we would need to make that information available, otherwise I think it's ok to use the same strategy and use the current state of required project.
This seems to be fairly well described below.
a jobs?
Done
shall require
Done
I don't see anything about this below.  How does the user go about doing this?
Next PS includes an example.

How does this work together with base jobs (e.g. log upload). Those secrets are generally not available to any user. I guess there is some filtering required to limit the playbooks that are being run? Or do we need some sort of job attribute that allows certain playbooks to be executed locally?

I think post actions are going to be important for people to test (fetching logs from test nodes, etc).  Maybe we could add 2 options, both disabled by default:

--post: run all post playbooks except the base job post playbook
--base-post: run the base job post playbook

But having an option to supply secrets may still be important.  For example, that could be very useful testing a docker upload job.  But maybe they can just be supplied as extra job variables.  How that looks may depend on what the input inventory looks like.

I think the matcher idea could work, but uniquely identifying a post playbook may be tricky.  Most of ours are named "post.yaml".  They would probably need to be fully qualified with the name of the repo and the path.

Still, I think specifying that you want to run everything except the log collection is a common enough use case that it should be easy, and adding "--post" 9 times for the 9 playbooks that you do want to run just to avoid running the 10th doesn't sound easy.  So if we do that, we may want to also have an inverse option, so a user could just say "--no-post opendev.org/base-jobs/playbooks/base/logs.yaml".

Further, it seems that if we're specifying the full path, we probably don't need to distinguish between pre and post?  Maybe we can just say "--no-playbook"?  It's unlikely that the same playbook would be used in both pre and post.  At least, no more likely than the same playbook showing up twice in pre or post.

Finally, maybe we could have an option to list the playbooks with numeric indexes.  So you could say "zuul-runner --list-playbooks" and it would print out:

0: opendev.org/base-jobs/playbooks/pre.yaml
...
10: opendev.org/base-jobs/playbooks/post.yaml

We could then say "--no-playbook 10" or "--no-playbook -1", or "--playbook 1..9".

I think we said that zuul-runner would not run post action. Alternatively we can detect such `site` secret and provide drop-in replacement that uses localhost, one of the initial implementation did that, but that is a bit tricky and skipping post-run seems easier.

I think just --post won't work in our environment because we have a stack of base jobs using post playbooks. I like the idea about the '--post <matcher>'. In think this should be an option that can be repeated to make it possible to select the post playbooks that are interesting to the user (same with --pre <matcher>'.
Or that could be implemented using a single `--post matcher` where matcher is a regular expression that select the playbook by name. Perhaps that can be done as a follow-up?
Having zuul-runner not executing post playbooks would solve this issue mostly I guess. But I think we should mention that in the spec as well.
It seems weird to have a 'depends-on' option with no change.  Perhaps the option should just be called "--change-url", and it could be a multiple-value option that points to change urls.
Done

It's probably obvious, but the zuul-executor should do little more than collect the job and run the zuul runner (at least in terms of code path, I wouldn't suggest the implementation necessarily call out to a zuul-runner binary).
That's correct, the zuul-runner shall re-use most of the zuul-executor code without interfering with the service

One of the big use cases I was originally designing this for was to try out new job definitions locally.

Being able to take an uncommitted set of changes to zuul.d/, point zuul-runner at an API endpoint, and have everything calculated and ran as if it were merged.

Perhaps that's not the scope of this spec though and could be future work.
Loading local zuul.d is indeed out of scope, the current implementation gets job details of an existing layout from the api. Though local ansible playbook modification are supported.

Perfect for the scope of this work, but I also envisioned it'd be awesome if a user could launch nodes in a cloud using images from nodepool or something just by supplying their own credentials (or libvirtd etc). This would likely be a big task though and certainly something outside of this spec.
I tried running nodepool driver locally with https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/nodepool/+/639632 for zuul-runner, but that more works needs to be specified for zuul-runner integration.

I think it could also be helpful to provide `--skip-pre-playbooks` and `--skip-post-playbooks` as I suspect they'll be most common.

Additionally a dry-run or keeping --list-playbooks to print out what will happen with the filters would be helpful.
Nit: if we do this, it probably should be "skip-playbook" or something similar so we don't back ourselves into a corner if there's something else we want to skip later.
(nit) how? As CLI params, a values.yaml etc?
I guess through a configuration file.

(nit) might be worth mentioning that this isn't complete. For example, it's missing the --list-playbooks and filters etc. I suspect the interface will change as the implementation grows so I wouldn't be too concerned about getting it right in the spec.
At some point we can remove the spec and replace it with the actual documentation.

I think in the long run, we want to track neutron's lower constraints, but I checked neutron locally and it fails lower-constraints as well. My assumption is that Neutron will probably fix this issue shortly (possibly in the same way) and when they do, we can mirror their fix. However, for the time being, in order to be able to merge changes, I think it's worth adopting this change.

cinder/volume/drivers/ibm/storwize_svc/s.message: pep8: E722 do not use bare 'except'
pep8: H201: no 'except:' at least use 'except Exception:'
pep8: F841 local variable 'e' is assigned to but never used
Why aren't we doing this before addvdiskaccess operation as done originally? that way we can avoid doing rmvdiskaccess in the except block

After checking the bug report, the failing method is addvdiskaccess and not movevdisk,
the way to do it seems right (i.e. execute movevdisk after addvdisk) but this exception block should enclose addvdisk and not this method

As per IBM documentation, addvdiskaccess is done before movevdisk.
https://www.ibm.com/support/knowledgecenter/STSLR9_8.2.1/com.ibm.fs9100_821.doc/svc_migratevdiskiogrpscli_42lens.html

And as per the defect, addvdiskaccess failed with error and movevdisk is already done.
So, we had to revert volume to older iogrp manually.
But with this fix, if addvdiskaccess fails, we do not move further and if movevdisk fails with exception, we do rmvdiskaccess in the except block.

Does smartnic support requires the [sriov_nic]/physical_device_mappings neutron configuration? If yes then:

To be able to use an SRIOV port today neutron needs to be configured at least with [sriov_nic]/physical_device_mappings . If neutron also have qos min bandwidth configuration then neutron starts reporting the device RPs and physnet traits.

What if we change neutron to report the device RPs and physnet traits already when [sriov_nic]/physical_device_mappings is configured, just not report the bandwidth resources until qos is configured.

This way Cyborg can assume that the device RP and the physnet trait is always created by neutron.

In this solution, we should consider the RP structure. Currently, cyborg report device RP direcly under compute node RP as a child. If bandwidth qos configured, the nic is reported under Agent RP.

I left some comment in the cyborg spec

On the PTG[1] we said that in the first step we would like to avoid the complication of representing one physical device twice, once by neutron from qos perspective and once by cyborg from accelerator perspective. 

While the above text solves the double representation by instructing cyborg admin to use the same name for the RP. It does not solve the issue of
* which services starts first and creates the RP tree while the other service waits for the RP tree
* does not handle the implicit ownership of the RPs (please note that the device RP is created under the neutron agent RP at the moment). E.g. neutron might try to delete the RPs after a configuration change while cyborg still depend on those RPs.

So I still suggest to state here (and document it later during the implementation) that a smart nic device that is handled by Cyborg should not be configured in neutron device mapping. And vice versa if a smartnic is used as an SRIOV device by neutron then it cannot be in parallel configured in cyborg.

[1] https://etherpad.opendev.org/p/nova-wallaby-ptg

If you need the neutron sriov agent to configure the smartNIC phyiscal device on the host then you need to configure the smartNIC device in the physical_device_mappings config.  > I agree with you that we should let Cyborg handle and report nic RP
 > and physnet trait to Placement.

What you definitely need to forbid is to configure resource_provider_bandwidths in neutron for a device that is also configured in Cyborg. As that would lead to RP conflict as both neutron and cyborg would try to create an RP for the same physical device.

(physical_device_mappings = physnet1:eth0)
will not create any RP in placement. It is used to locate the nic in a certain network.  If we do not configure this, we can not boot a VM with sriov port. Please correct me if I missed some info.

So without Qos enabled, we need fetch the physnet from the port info, can convert it to trait as some kind of format(Could you show the format in this spec). But if we have port with qos, then  port will return a physnet trait from the port info, then you needn't convert it manually. It will be great the neutron port always return physnet trait, instead of convert it manually.

Probably neutron will return physnet trait when the vnic type is cyborg or with qos.

According to https://docs.openstack.org/neutron/latest/admin/config-qos-min-bw.html#debugging, if qos is configured, the physnet traits looks like CUSTOM_PHYSNET_PHYSNET0, so I prefer that nova converts the physnet name to this format as well. Besides, cyborg should report physnet traits with the same format. 

As for the translator, in terms of qos, it is neutron who read from its config file and translate the resource needs into the standard format of resource classes or traits. I suggest we can simply let nova do this translation, because nova need not only the physnet trait, but also need to know the physnet for other usage, for example, https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/master/nova/network/neutron.py#L2151.

It is an open question, as my reply to alex. I prefer that nova get the physnet name from port, and generate a physnet trait by itself, then nova should fill port resource request with this trait. 

Another option is that, let neutron generation physnet trait and fill it in port resource request. And nova only need to get this trait from neutron. 

I personally prefer the first option, because we still need get physnet name string from neutorn anyway, for other usages. 

How we decide finally, it need nova and neutron folks to get an agreement.
